sections.title: Decision-Making Pitfalls
sections.content: Common mistakes include making decisions based on emotions, following the crowd, or ignoring long-term consequences. Financial decisions are often complex and involve uncertainty, making them particularly prone to cognitive biases and emotional influences.

points.title: Pros and Cons Analysis
points.description: List the advantages and disadvantages of each option before deciding.

points.title: Cost-Benefit Analysis
points.description: Quantify the costs and benefits of different choices when possible.

points.title: Opportunity Cost Consideration
points.description: Remember that choosing one option means giving up alternatives.

sections.title: Sleep on Big Decisions
sections.content: For major financial decisions, give yourself time to think. Sleep on it, discuss with trusted advisors, and avoid making decisions under emotional stress.

sections.title: When to Seek Professional Help
sections.content: Complex situations like tax planning, estate planning, or major investment decisions often benefit from professional advice. Choose fee-only financial advisors who are fiduciaries. Know when DIY is sufficient and when expertise is needed.

sections.title: Improve Your Decision Making
steps: Identify a recent financial decision and analyze what you could have done better
Create a decision-making checklist for major financial choices
Practice delayed decision-making for non-urgent choices
Build a network of trusted financial advisors for complex situations

sections.title: Learn from Mistakes
sections.content: Everyone makes financial mistakes. The key is learning from them. Keep a decision journal to track your thinking process and outcomes.
